Fields.DialogueText: Captain! You're so busy lately. I'm so glad I finally ran into you.
We live on the same ship, Henley.
Right, well. Anyway, since I've got you here, I wanted to ask you...
Not now, Henley. The radio's hot, and the message is clear. There's danger loose in these waters.
Wait! It'll only take a second. You've got time for a short speech from your favorite culinary student, don't you?

Fields.MenuText: Sorry, Henley, but the safety of the people aboard this ship is all I have time for.
All right, Henley, keep it brief!
Henley, that's a cue for you to scan the deck. This is not the time.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not such a big ship, Captain. I'll run into you again, and I will keep pestering you!
Really? All right, I'll try to talk as fast as I can.
Oh please, Captain. Sure, I may bump my knees against the corners of tables frequently, but I've never let a Morgana sneak up on me.
Captain! We've got Morganas closing fast!
Sometimes I hate good intel. Prepare for battle. Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Looks as if we've pushed them away for now.
Got that right. Good sailing, Captain. Now, as I was saying...
Captain, the radio!
What is it, Henley?
Um... Well, I was just going to...
This better be good, Henley. I've got a huge checklist of operations that I haven't even cracked into yet.
Well, I'm no sleuth, but the look on your face makes me guess that radio call wasn't a wedding invitation.
You're one perceptive woman, Henley. The word is out. This area is basically infested with Morganas. Endless sightings we're talking about here...
Plus Command is breathing down my neck for an overhaul of on-board supplies, as if this were the right time.
Right, well... Don't worry about me. I'll just come back another time.

Fields.MenuText: Good thinking, Henley. Hey, do me a favor and check how many life vests we have down in storage, will you?
Wait. Were you going to ask me something?
Listen, I'd love to chat, but the only thing on my mind is coming up with a plan in case we get pigeonholed.

Fields.DialogueText: Sure. No problem, Captain. That's exactly what I would love to do.
Oh yeah, heh... Funny you should mention it. I almost forgot. There was one thing I wanted to talk you about...
Silly me. I should have known. You do suit your role well, Captain.
*ALARM*
Damn! The alarm... Morganas must have found us again already.
Waiting on your call, Captain.
You know what to do.
@BATTLE
Scanning the horizon again, Captain? I wonder if you ever find what it is you're looking for.
Perhaps safety is something that simply can't be found. You've got some red sauce on your collar, by the way.
Oh, darn! Really? Well, ever since you taught me how to make that sweet, delicious spaghetti dish, I just... I can't help myself.

Fields.MenuText: Right. Well, perhaps next time you can clean your uniform off after.
Well, that must mean I'm a good teacher. A friend of mine once said to me "You're not eating it unless you're wearing it."
Where's mine, Henley?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I try so hard not to let my clumsiness get the best of me. You must think I'm so sloppy.
Ha! I like your friend already. There's a little bit left over if you want any.
You've just been so busy recently. I figured you wouldn't have time to eat it.
I'm glad you're putting your newfound skills to work.
Which is exactly what I've wanted to talk to you about. I've created a new recipe, and I really want you to try it.
A new recipe? Forgive me, Henley, but I can't help but feel the least bit scared. What are you going to make?
Very funny, Captain. It's a surprise. Look, all you have to do is pick a time to come down to the galley and have dinner with me. Is that really so crazy?
No... Henley, look to the port. That's a fleet of Morganas over there.
Well, you better hurry up and tell me! What do you say, Captain?
What do I say? I say we really need to focus on the fleet of Morgana ships coming towards us. Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Ah-ha! We live to fight another day, Captain.
You're a bold girl, Henley, and you fight like hell. Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to go check the status of our weapons.
Wait... Captain! What about dinner?
Captain, I'm seeing more of that face every time I see you. You should stop to eat more often. What is it this time?
Oh, nothing too major, Henley. Just some potential issues in the engine room!
Hmmm... I have felt a little hot recently, although I thought it could have been the canned sardines.
Listen, I really must be going. There's a group already waiting on me down there.
I guess if you say so, Captain, but after you deal with this... fever, promise me you'll come and try my new recipe. Won't you, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: War is a busy time to be a ship captain, Henley. I can't make any promises.
Listen Henley, we're pigeon-holed here, I'm booked solid. But I'll try to sneak away for a while. I will.
I probably am going to be starving by then. Why not, Henley?

Fields.DialogueText: Ooh, I'll find some way to get it to you. Maybe bat my eyes at the cooks...
Thanks, Captain! You always make me feel better.
All right! Now I'm as excited as on graduation day!
Looks like I won't be heading to the engine room straight away after all.
You're coming to the galley?
I wish that were true. Look to the bow, Henley.
Ah! These Morganas better not spoil our ingredients!
Can they do that?
@BATTLE
Their shells can be... different. Not every time, but sometimes. Long story.
Good news, Henley!
The war is over and you're going to take me all over the French countryside where we can eat baguette sandwiches together!?

Fields.MenuText: What! Henley, quit daydreaming - it's dangerous at sea.
You're a riot, Henley. That's why I love sailing with you.

Fields.DialogueText: As if I could help it, Captain! You can't tell me that you don't have daydreams floating in your head, too.
Aw, you mean it, Captain? Definitely helps that I chose you, right?
The problem in the engine room has been taken care of.
Oh, right! I thought so. I thought I could feel my fever going away earlier.
Ah... Well, why didn't you say something?
Hm. Guess I just lose track when I'm hungry. So can you come to the galley now?
*ALARM*
Uncanny timing. You know the drill when you hear that sound.
Morganas? Again!?
I'm guessing hunger wreaks havoc on your senses.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You know that's not possible.

Fields.DialogueText: Has anyone tried, Captain? Maybe if you took a piece of me inland, I could at least sense it...
Don't tell my sisters?
Is everything all right, Captain? You're starting to look like me after I haven't eaten in a while.
It's funny you ask, Henley, because no. Everything is not all right.
You want to talk about it?
We've got electronics malfunctioning in the control room, the radio is crackling in and out, and with the chance of a storm coming, we might not be pushing on anytime soon.
So what you're saying, Captain, is that you finally have the time to come and try my new secret recipe?

Fields.MenuText: How can you even think about food in a time like this, Henley? No! There's just too much on our plate right now.
Well, a storm might break any minute, and I guess there's no point in trying to radio out. Looks like you've got me, Henley. I'm your galley captive.
Henley, look... I'd really love to, but there are just too many problems going on right now.

Fields.DialogueText: You mean at a time when our destruction is fingertips away? That's the best time to think about food, Captain. Perhaps you don't have enough on your plate.
galley captive? Listen, I just want you to try my food. I'm not going to tie you up or anything.
Hm. Never heard that one before, Captain. Guess I'll just eat alone again... Eat the loneliness away.
Henley, look. I know I've been busy recently, but this is war. Our safety is my number one priority.
You know, you remind me of the friends back at William and Mary, Captain. I used to love the times we had together.
Well, thanks, Henley!
Then we graduated, and they never talked to me again...
What?
Captain! Look portside. Morgana ships spotted. What's your command?
Good eyes, sailor. You know the call. Let's show these Morganas what we're capable of.
@BATTLE
Looks like we've pushed them away, for now at least. Good work, Henley. I can always count on you to charge into battle.
Now you're making me hungry.
And to have dinner ready when it's over?
Yay! It's working!
Captain! What a surprise to see you down here. Is there some crisis with the food pantry?
Not unless you cleared all the food out.
Very funny, Captain. What exactly are you trying to say?
Oh stop, Henley. We both know you are lar... uh... you have a large appetite. I'm playing around with you.
Huh! Don't tell me, Captain. You came down here to... to try my recipe?
Guilty as charged. Now, on the double, Henley! I do have a ship I need to get back to running.
But, Captain, you didn't even give me any notice. I'm not ready. Oh! Please don't let this be a reflection of my chef skills... Can you come back in a little while?

Fields.MenuText: Are you serious, Henley? You incessantly beg me to come down here, I finally find the time, and you're not ready?
I can't promise anything. This ship isn't going to run itself. But, I'll try to make my way back here.
Or else miss out on my star pupil's new recipe? No way, Henley! You let me know when you're ready and I'll come back right away.

Fields.DialogueText: You didn't even give me any notice, Captain! This is your fault as much as mine. A friendship works two ways, Captain.
You'd better, Captain. I don't want to have to leave it under your bed!
Really, Captain? You're a hell of a motivator. You won't be disappointed!
*BOOM*
Damn! Seems the Morganas have found their way back to us already.
Guess the only thing we'll be eating is barbecued cruiser.
Some meat sauce might cut the tang of the steel.
Ha! That's not the only thing that can cut steel!
@BATTLE
Candles and wine? Wow, Henley. Seems you've really outdone yourself.
At ease, Captain! Take a seat; the food will be done in just a sec. Here, have some wine.
This is certainly more than I expected. What's the meaning of all this?
What do you mean, Captain? All I want is for you to try my new dish and to celebrate all that we've been through.
Hmm... if you say so. It's just that, well, this feels like a date, Henley.
What was that? Well, never mind. Get ready for an explosion of flavor, Captain! Here it is: my secret dish.
Mmm! It smells delicious, Henley. A minced meat pie, huh? You've really outdone yourself.
Just wait until you try some, Captain. Here, have a taste...
Pft! Henley, put the fork down. I can feed myself, come on. What is this? Henley, you're trying to come onto me, I know it!
Well, so what if I am, Captain! I just want to spend some time with you again, and maybe this is the only way I can have that. Don't you find me attractive?

Fields.MenuText: Henley, we've been through this. I thought I made it clear. I'm not interested in anything other than friendship.
Listen Henley, I'm sure there's somebody out there for you. You're a beautiful lady. But that someone is not me.
That outfit does look especially nice on you, Henley.

Fields.DialogueText: Right... of course, Captain. It's presumptuous of me to frame it like this.
You're an admirable person, Captain. But you don't have to say those things just to make me feel better.
You mean it, Captain? I was born with it, but I... I do try.
Henley... Are you ok? Oh, don't cry. Come on now... What's wrong?
Don't worry about it, Captain. You're probably too busy to listen anyway.
No, wait, Henley...
*ALARM*
Oh... Nobody said war would be easy.
@BATTLE
Haha! The Morganas run again. You would think they would learn by now. Henley? Henley, are you ok?
Just fine, Captain. I think I'll go clean up in the galley... forever...
She can't be serious.
Look Henley, I don't care if I have a million things on my schedule. I'm going to sit here until you tell me what's wrong.
You've had your chance, Captain. I'll just talk to my tuna sandwich, just like I always do!
Come on, Henley. Save the dramatics. Here, take this tissue. Look, I'm trying to be a friend here.
Oh, well, that's a first!
Care to elaborate? First you try to wine and dine me, then you try spoon-feeding me, and now you're crying... Are you still harboring feelings for me, Henley?
Oh, Captain. For a ship commander you can be so blind sometimes.
Well, when you leave me in a fog like this...
I just feel like... Well, since you told me that... that you just want to be friends, I just feel like... I feel like you never give me any attention anymore.
What?
You're always shuffling around, too busy to talk to me. You say we're friends, but you never have time for me. Was that your plan all along?
Plan? My only plan is surviving the war. What are you talking about, Henley?
I know the tactics, Captain. You just told me we could be friends so that you never had to talk to me again. Isn't that right?

Fields.MenuText: I guess you figured out my master plan, Henley. You're too smart for your own good. Sorry.
Oh, Henley, I fear that those unfortunate college friendships have tainted your views. I'm sorry I can't always be there. I promise it's solely on account of my naval obligations.
I had no idea you felt that way, Henley. I'm so sorry. But you chose me. That means I'm not going anywhere. No matter what.

Fields.DialogueText: You're a monster, Captain! I can't believe I ever thought you were attractive!
Perhaps you're right, Captain. I'm sorry. Maybe I've been a bit overbearing.
You're a great sailor, but a horrible detective. I guess I shouldn't have signed you up to be one.
Henley, I said I want to be your friend because I want to be your friend. I'm a busy sailor. I've got no time for amiable deception.
If you say so, Captain... Maybe I just need a sandwich. That might be the best thing for all this overthinking I've been doing.
Hold the bread, Henley. Look out that window. Morganas!
@BATTLE
Wait... oh. I get it. Heh... I didn't mean that.
Captain?
What is it, Henley? We finally got the radio back up, and word is that there's a fleet of Morganas headed our direction. Make it quick.
Right, of course. Never mind, I'll just come back later.
No, wait! Henley... What is it? Just because my eyes are focused doesn't mean my ears can't be too. What is it?
Thanks, Captain! I'll be really brief. I just wanted to know what you thought about my new recipe.
Right, the new recipe...
Yeah, the minced pie! Remember, silly? Did it taste good?

Fields.MenuText: Oh right, the pie! Um... I... uh, didn't really have enough to give a good review. Sorry, Henley.
Ok, how do I put this lightly? It kind of tasted like a hot ball of sand.
Absolutely. The flavor was, it was... certainly unique.

Fields.DialogueText: Aw, well, that's ok, Captain. I appreciate your honesty. Guess you'll just have to try it again soon!
Captain! That was putting it lightly? Oh, I really thought I had a good mix.
Really? The look on your face, Captain, makes me want to not believe you.
Well listen, Captain. There was another reason I wanted you to try my meat pie recipe.
How did I know there was going to be something more to this?
Maybe you're psychic, Captain. A psychic sailor... That has a nice ring to it!
It was a rhetorical question, Henley.
Captain! The crew spotted Morgana ships flanking from starboard.
Looks like you'll have to tell me later, Henley. We've got work to do. Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Are you going to help me with the munitions preparation or just stand there and look at that paper scrap all day?
Oh... I just don't get it.
What's there to get? Put the scrap paper down and put your eyes on this turret. What could you possibly be staring at for so long, anyway?
It's my pie recipe, Captain. I've gone over it a hundred times. All the ingredients and amounts seem right, so why doesn't it taste good?!
Let me see that thing. Sardines, canned tuna, one cup of salt... Are you kidding me, Henley? This recipe is horrible.
Ah! That's no way to talk to a lady, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Look, Henley, I'm just trying to be a good friend. Good friends are honest to each other.
Sorry, Henley. Next time I'll just lie to you. I think you've got a real winner dinner here!
Ah, I guess you're right, Henley. But come on, I taught you better than this.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, well, when you put it that way... Thanks, Captain. I guess your heart's in the right place.
Amazing. You've somehow found a way to be even more rude than you already are!
I'm sorry, Captain! Oh... I'm not good at anything, I swear.
Is it hopeless, Captain? Don't tell me it's hopeless.
Well, as it stands, yes - I think this recipe is utterly hopeless. But, I have faith that with a little, or a lot of work, we can turn this into something edible... even appetizing.
You mean it, Captain? You're talking to a William and Mary graduate here. I'm willing to listen and learn again.
Why is this so important to you, anyway?
Well, there is something I wanted to tell you.
Go on.
*ALARM*
Damn! Morganas.
Looks like we'll have to cook the only thing I'm good at making.
Henley, this is no time for cooking.
Charred Morgana stew.
Your jokes need some work, Henley. But I love your enthusiasm. Now get ready to fight!
@BATTLE
Well, Captain, the thing is...
Spit it out, Henley. I've got a meeting in the operations room soon.
Well, I'm a proud graduate of the College of William and Mary...
You don't say.
And, well, every year in Williamsburg where the college is located, there is a massive festival.
Look, Henley, I'd love to reminisce on your college days, but I really need to get a handle on the matters at hand.
Wait, Captain. Every year there's a massive festival, and one of the big events is a cooking competition, and you'll never guess who won the year I graduated.
How am I supposed to know, Henley? The school mascot?
Shirley Averson! Do you remember who that is?

Fields.MenuText: Your college dorm-room nemesis? How could I forget!
Sorry, Henley, I've got a lot on my mind recently. Can you refresh my memory?
Oh, Shirley! Right, of course, I knew that.

Fields.DialogueText: Hey, you really do remember! You're a great listener, Captain.
Do you ever even listen to me, Captain? Never mind...
Oh please, Captain. You're not putting one over on me. You have no idea who I'm talking about.
All right, all right. So why are you telling me this?
I figure if I start crafting my perfect recipe now, then who knows? Maybe one day I'll take the first-place prize.
Something tells me the prize is not all you want.
You're right, Captain. Nothing would make me happier than to see Shirley lose in front of her stupid boyfriend!
Good old-fashioned revenge, huh? I think now I'm starting to see how you became a destroyer.
Well, Captain?
What do you mean, well? It's a good story, Henley, but you haven't told me what I have to do with any of this.
*BOOM*
And let me guess: I'm going to have to wait to tell you until after this battle.
You're smarter than you let on, Henley. Now cut the chatter and get to the turrets!
@BATTLE
Captain! What are you looking at?
Nothing...yet. But the word on the wire is several Morgana ships have been spotted approaching from this direction. It's a good time to have eyes open.
Good thinking, Captain. Always staying one step ahead. Now perhaps I can convince you to open your ears, too?
Why do I get the feeling you're going to ask me for a favor?
Was that another rhetorical question, Captain?
You're getting better, Henley.
Right, thanks. Well, remember I told you about the festival and the cooking competition back in Williamsburg?
I haven't forgotten.
And I'm working on my minced meat pie recipe...
It is indeed a work in progress.
... In so many words. But that's what I wanted to ask you, Captain. You can help me! You can help me turn my recipe into a masterpiece.
Oh, lord. As if I wasn't busy enough.
Come on, Captain. You know I've got your back. Help me with my recipe. Help me cook something that can win the cookoff and destroy Shirley!
I don't know...
What do you say, Captain? Can you help me with my recipe?

Fields.MenuText: I'm swamped, Henley. My hands are tied right now, but I'll try my best to find the time.
Sorry, Henley. But a naval vessel is not culinary school. We just don't have time for this right now.
I owe it to you. Let's make a pie that will surely make Shirley cry!

Fields.DialogueText: That sounds like an excuse, Captain. Just be honest. It's okay if you don't want to help me.
Right, silly me for even thinking about anything other than death, destruction, and war.
Ah! I love your attitude, Captain. That's the best news I've heard all day.
Well, maybe we can make this work. But it will have to be another time. Look to the port. Morgana ships approaching quick.
Well, let's kick them out of here so we can get back to making a pie!
Whatever motivates you, Henley...
@BATTLE
Try not to look so glum, Henley! It's bad for crew morale, and we need as much as we can get right now.
Yeah, sure. I'll try my best.
Oh come on now, I can't have a downhearted ship to sail with. What's eating you?
You never gave me a straight answer back there, Captain. I thought you were going to come help me with this pie, but you've been unavailable.

Fields.MenuText: I've always got time for reputable crew members, Henley, but the war demands my absolute attention. We need to stay focused.
Sorry, Henley, there's a flood of thoughts and tasks blitzing my brain right now. I just forgot.
War is a lot of waiting around, Henley. You're going to have to wait.

Fields.DialogueText: You've seen what we're capable of. Surely we've earned something tasty for our down time.
I can definitely relate. If something grabs my attention I'm not likely to let go until it's done.
Well, it's a straight answer. If a disappointing one.
Henley, no offense, but who even knows the next time you're going to be back in Williamsburg?
Captain, you and I know that preparation is one of the most important aspects of winning. Haven't we proven that again and again against the Morganas?
I guess it is pretty unreasonable to expect a victory without at least a little practice.
That's all I ask, Captain. That and a little perspective from your end.
You weren't joking about that, were you?
If it smells good, it's ready. And it smells good much more often than not.
Sounds like you're halfway to winning that cookoff already.
*ALARM*
Yay! Now, if I could just cook something to poison those Morganas...
Let's leave subtlety for later. Guns blazing, Henley!
@BATTLE
... Besides, someone has to make sure I don't eat the ingredients halfway through.
It's like you're a pie scholar. That crust is amazing, Captain.
Don't ask me how I know how to do that. Now we have to consider the filling.
Well?
Well? Well, what do you like? Not canned tuna.
Well... I don't know. There's not much I don't like to eat, really. What do you suggest?

Fields.MenuText: How about minced beef?
A shredded chicken would work well, I think.
I bet a minced pork would make this really something.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain! That sounds absolutely delicious. Yes!
Maybe. I'd prefer something a little richer, though.
Mmm... good, really good. Maybe with some brown sugar...
You start tending to the meat. I'm going to set up the burner.
Aye-aye, Captain! I can't wait to see Shirley call my pie delicious.
That doesn't sound so bad.
And then find out it was me and get red with embarrassment!
Henley, I've never told you this, but I think you may have some resentment issues.
What! No... What are you talking about, Captain? Did she get to you?
It'll have to be another time, Henley. Morgana ships starboard. Positions, everyone!
@BATTLE
So we've got the filling completed. The crust is ready to go. What's the next step, Henley?
Throw it in the oven?
No, Henley! Come on, think about it...
Fold the crust over the top?
You're learning, Henley. I like it.
Like that?
That's it, Henley. Perfect. Now, the trick is that you have to poke a couple of holes in the top crust of the pie.
Seems kind of like an unnecessary step, Captain.
Quite the opposite, in fact. If you don't poke holes, then the steam and heat will build up and get trapped in the pie.
It's never a good idea to let things build up.
Funny you should say that...
And what exactly is that supposed to mean, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Uh... Nothing! You're just one sharp girl, Henley. I figured you would know!
Ah, don't worry about it, Henley. If you don't get it now, you'll probably never understand.
Henley, I'm not trying to be rude. Just... remember our last conversation? I'm just trying to help.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, you act like I can't tell when you are lying. You should give me a little more credit by now.
Gee, Captain, you really know how to boost someone's confidence.
And all I'm trying to do is get you to explain what you mean.
Listen, remember when I said you might have some resentment issues built up?
What... Oh, you mean that joke you said before? Wait, that was a joke, right?
Um...
Captain! Morgana ships have been spotted starboard. What's your call?
I appreciate your respect for the chain of command, Officer, but I shouldn't even have to call this one. Prepare to fire.
Wait, Captain... You're not sneaking out of this one.
Sorry, Henley, but it will just have to wait. Use that resentment to get rid of these damn Morganas.
What resentment!?
Just imagine that Shirley is the Morgana captain.
Ah! What are we waiting for, Captain? Charge!
@BATTLE
Looks like we finally have a break from these endless Morgana assaults.
Just enough time to get that pie in the oven!
It's looking good already. I'm impressed. Have you been taking notes?
Extensively, Captain. See?
On a napkin, Henley? Surely there must have been a notebook floating around here somewhere.
Don't worry, Captain. I did all of my studying in the mess hall at good old William and Mary. Most of my study notes were on napkins!
Your professors must have been so proud.
So, time to throw this delicious mix in the oven?
Not yet, Henley. First we have to let it warm up. Just turn the switch, and... Now we wait.
Great! Just one step closer to my... our award-winning recipe! Now we even have some time to talk and catch up a bit.
Catch up? Henley, it's not like we haven't been seeing each other a lot lately.
Any opportunity to talk with a dear friend is a good opportunity. Wouldn't you say, Captain?
Captain! Command is on the radio and asking for you.
Excuse me, Henley. Keep an eye on the oven. I'll be back when I can.
Wait, Captain! Don't go yet... Command can wait a while.

Fields.MenuText: For heaven's sake, Henley, have you forgotten we're at war here? I need to go.
I'll stay until we get the pie in the oven. Then I need to go.
Look, Henley, I'd love to spend some more time together, but you never know what Command has to say. It could be urgent.

Fields.DialogueText: Sure, you say you're going to war, but we both know you're just running away! From me!
You mean it, Captain? You really do care.
And this pie isn't urgent? My master recipe isn't urgent? It's not like we can refrigerate it, Captain!
Calm down, Henley. Sometimes you can be so...
So what, Captain?
*BOOM*
Forget about it, Henley! Seems Command isn't the only one trying to get my attention. You really want to spend more time with me? Then help me with these damn enemy ships!
@BATTLE
I can be so what, Captain? What can I be so--
What are you talking about, Henley? Surely this can wait for another time. I'm trying to get through to Command right now.
No, Captain! This can't wait. You said, and I quote, "Sometimes you can be so..." And then you stopped.
Oh come on, Henley. You're not going to hold that against me, are you?
I think I deserve to know what you were going to say, Captain!
Captain... Captain... Can you read me? This is Command, over.
Henley, please can this wait? This could be potentially life-saving news.
Just tell me what you were going to say! Then I'll leave you alone.

Fields.MenuText: Fine, I'll tell you after the radio call.
Sorry, Henley. But it's my decision, and I've decided not to tell you.
I guess you're right; you do deserve to know. Ok, I'll tell you.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah, sure you will. It's always after something.
I will get to the bottom of this, Captain! See if I don't.
Thank you, Captain. Finally I see you really do respect me.
Captain? Captain? Do you read me?
Yeah, Captain? Can you read me?
Fine, Henley! You really want to know? I was going to tell you that sometimes you can be overbearing, smothering, and overwhelming.
*BOOM*
Look, I'm sorry, Henley. Oh, hell... Now's not the time for tears.
You really think that, Captain?
Not now, Henley! There's Morganas about. Get it together. Positions, everyone!
@BATTLE
Captain? Captain?
What is it, Henley? Is it urgent? Excuse my sour expression, but I've finally just spoken to Command. An ally ship south of here just went down. Morganas, they think.
Definitely urgent, Captain. Did you really mean it when you called me overbearing?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not the type of person to make comments I don't mean.
Well, yes, but don't you kind of know that already?
Another time, Henley. I need to come up with a plan in case there are enemy ships at our back.

Fields.DialogueText: I see. You know what I think, Captain? I think you hide behind that wall of bluntness.
Well, I, um. Captain! Okay, maybe the thought had crossed my mind once or twice.
You really know what you're doing, Captain. Perhaps we shouldn't ignore the signs. Maybe I'll let this one slide.
Henley, I would love to sit and chat about your hurt feelings, but now's not the time to idly sit by while more ally ships sink.
You want to come up with a strategy, and I want an explanation - and, well, maybe a sandwich - but why do you think I'm overbearing? Just answer me while you make your plan!
Henley, Henley. Just give me a moment.
No!
See, this is exactly the type of thing I'm talking about.
Wait, what?
You're acting kind of crazy right now.
Captain! Looks like we've spotted some enemy ships fast approaching from the south.
Just... Channel that craziness, Henley. Let's survive this, and then we can talk all you want. Maybe I'll even pop something in the oven for you.
Oh, no... Captain! The oven!
There's no time, Henley. Let's try and deal with these Morganas before we burn the whole galley down.
@BATTLE
Be careful, Captain! I don't sense that the oven's on fire, but it's definitely hot.
Grab me the oven mitts.
Do you want the red ones, or the blue?
Damn it, Henley! Why would that matter?
Fine, you can have one of each.
Thanks. Quick, turn the knob down.
Got it!
Last thing: get me a glass of water.
There's no fire.
No, but there's a lot of smoke.
Oh, it's for you...
I'm just thirsty. I think we caught a lucky break there, Henley.
Good thing I said something! Hey, can we still throw the pie in?

Fields.MenuText: I don't know if that's a good idea. Maybe we should just stay out of the galley for a while.
Sure! We're trying to make a competition-winning recipe here, right?
I think I'm going to go with the safest option, here. I'm out on this one, Henley. Sorry, I'm done.

Fields.DialogueText: A while? How long is a while, Captain? I'm really not sure if that's a good idea.
I should start calling you Tuna Melt because you always make me feel better, Captain!
Well I can't help but say that I'm a bit disappointed. But, I'm not going to act overbearing here. I'm not going to do it. Nope, everything is totally fine...
It'd be a brig-worthy crime to let this food go to waste, though. I suppose we should cook it eventually.
Now?
Calm yourself, Henley. Not now, the oven is just now recuperating from a near conflagration!
Right... Wait, what?
Come on, Henley. I thought you were a William and Mary graduate...
I knew what you meant, Captain. I simply couldn't hear you.
Well, I hope you can hear this... I want to apologize.
For...?
I shouldn't have called you overbearing.
But I am, Captain.
You've... accepted this now?
*BOOM*
I've been doing some thinking, Captain. I'll tell you all about it.
Now's a better time to put your mind to the enemy at hand.
Don't worry about me, Captain. I'll just smother them to death.
You're a real hoot, Henley. Do whatever it takes.
@BATTLE
Think it's about time to pop that meat pie back in the cooker, Captain?
As much as I'd love to say something about how my naval obligations have my hands tied, I actually have no excuse this time.
Really!?
Command wants us to sit tight until they get more communications from down south. We better get that pie in the oven now, before that meat sits out.
Then to the galley we go!
Your enthusiasm is nothing short of inspiring, Henley.
Because for once, I didn't have to beg you to come and help me.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe if you didn't beg me so much, I'd find more space in my busy schedule more often.
Henley, it's not that I don't want to spend time with you, but running a ship... dealing with you, it's a full time job!
Oh, stop it, Henley!

Fields.DialogueText: Ugh! That's a rude thing to say, Captain... but not completely invalid.
As it should be, Captain. A girl like me deserves your best efforts.
Right! Sorry, Captain. Sometimes I can be so odd!
I've changed, you know. The old me would have begged you to come and help with the food. The new Henley? She doesn't beg, she understands.
Easier on all of us. I think you've got a much healthier perspective on things now.
And then when we perfect this recipe, I'll have a masterpiece that will put Shirley Averson to shame, and we'll get to eat!
Calm down, Henley.
It's perfect!
Captain!
Just a moment, Officer. Sorry Henley, I need to go. We'll pick this up again later, ok?
No, wait... Captain, how are we ever going to get back at Shirley with you running off like this?
We're stuck on a ship, Henley. I'm not running anywhere. Did you ever think that maybe your feelings about Shirley could have inspired your overbearing nature?
What!?
Captain!
Officer! Let me guess, Morganas?
*BOOM*
@BATTLE
The pie is in the oven and cooking, Captain.
All by yourself, huh?
I can handle it. I think... Who knows the next time I'll be back in Williamsburg? I've got plenty of time to perfect my revenge weapon.
You're starting to sound scary, Henley. Save that talk for the fight. Listen, I'm glad I was able to assist you with the recipe...
But? You're going to say "but," aren't you?
But I've developed suspicions that your feelings toward Shirley may be affecting your judgement.
Captain, what do you mean?

Fields.MenuText: Do I really have to spell this out for you?
Henley, I think you know what I mean. I'm just looking out for your best interest.
Human emotions are a complex puzzle, Henley. Sometimes we just have to know when to let go.

Fields.DialogueText: If you still want me to be nice to you!
How do you know what's in my best interest, Captain?
Oh... I see.
Look, Henley, I know your good friend betrayed you, and that's a scarring experience...
It wasn't that big of a deal, you know?
And that's why you can't go clinging to every one of your other friends until you suffocate the life out of them.
*ALARM*
Just think on it, Henley. Positions, everyone! Morganas starboard.
@BATTLE
So, Captain? Excuse me, Captain?
Make it quick, Henley. Command has just received word from the south, and they're going to wire the news to me soon.
I just need some clarification. So what you were saying earlier; you think I get really attached to my friends because of that thing that happened with Shirley?

Fields.MenuText: Yep, that's it. Exactly what I think.
You seem to have a part of the picture, but there's more to it than that.
Don't worry about it, Henley. I think this whole thing requires a self-awareness I'm not sure you've developed yet.

Fields.DialogueText: You think you're so smart, Captain.
Oh, okay... Well, don't leave me in the dark!
What? What kind of rude, offhand comment is that, Captain?
I'm sorry if I offended you, Henley. I've always found honesty to be the most admirable course of action, even at the risk of causing offense.
Right. So what you're saying is that if I forget about this whole thing with Shirley - just forget about the whole thing - then maybe I'll be less overbearing?
It's worth a shot! I mean, how long has it been since your college days anyway?
Hey! Are you saying I look old?
Shouldn't that pie be done cooking already?
Uh...
Henley! Damn, look out the window. Morganas. Great, as if almost burning down the galley once wasn't enough!
@BATTLE
Thanks for coming to see me, Captain. I have a confession.
What's on your mind, Henley?
... I never went to William and Mary.
You what?
I have an honorary degree. They ran my picture in the yearbook and sent me a ring...but I've never set foot on campus. I'm a Belle. There's no way.
But... your memories? Your sister? Shirley? Where is that from?
Belle memories are strange, Captain... a lot of who we are comes from where we're from. It's like something's... lodged in my head, even if I didn't truly live it.
I'm sorry. You must think I'm so weird.
I do. But Henley... that's just the way you're built.
Captain?
It's your life story, however you came by it. Good and bad, it gives you a purpose. But when I look at you, I don't see Shirley's archenemy or Ralph's sister.
I see one of the most ambitious ships in the fleet. I wish my crew had half your passion.
You really mean it?
Every word.
Henley... Is that the pie?
Isn't it beautiful, Captain?
Seems to be a miracle. I guess you pulled it out just at the right time. A delicious smell like that can make a sailor forget they're at war.
Well, I didn't do it alone, Captain. I owe a big thanks to you, you know?
I didn't do much, Henley. You've always been the star pupil.
Please, Captain. You sound sweeter than a slice of cake.
Well, there's been no mention of Shirley, or any far-off revenge plans.
My mind's been right here lately. Perhaps I owe you for helping me with more than just the pie.
Don't mention it, Henley. Now listen: I'm scheduled to correspond with Command about news from the south.
Aw, but you can't leave without sharing some of this food with me first! What do you say - have a slice?

Fields.MenuText: I really shouldn't. I have a schedule to keep.
One slice can't hurt! It'd be a shame not to try the finished product.
Sorry, Henley. There's potential danger lurking on the southern horizon.

Fields.DialogueText: And that's totally fine! Yep, no problem at all.
That's right, Captain. How else will your star student improve?
All the more reason to start on this pie!
*BOOM*
Damn! Looks like Command is going to have to stand by.
@BATTLE
Uh-oh... The radio call with Command didn't go very well, did it?
And what gives you that impression, detective?
Well there's the brisk ferocity of your stride, and it looks a little like you're clenching your upper and lower jaws together, plus you keep running your hand through your hair...
All right, all right!
Wait. Oh darn! Was that another rhetorical question.
We're in trouble, Henley. Command has word that there's a navy-sized fleet bee-lining from the south, straight for us. A few ships have already gone down.
I had a strange feeling that something like this was going to happen.
No one can say you're not perceptive.
You didn't let me finish, Captain! I was going to say this is why I saved the meat pie!
You didn't need to eat it?
Not yet. I wanted to share it with you.
Henley, thanks. Look, I'm flattered, but we need to prepare for battle.
Don't worry, Captain. All the preparations are finished already. I took care of it. Just come and eat with me.
I don't know, Henley. The odds are against us.
All the more reason, Captain. Who knows if we'll make it through this time.
Look starboard, Henley. I can already start to see some of them. Morgana shapes.
Captain, I just want you to know that, whatever happens, you've been a really good friend to me. Thank you for everything.

Fields.MenuText: No need to thank me. A friendship works two ways. We're a team, Henley.
You didn't make it easy sometimes, Henley. But sailing with you has been a real pleasure.
Less talking, more eating! You're a true friend, Henley, but we're running out of time to dig into this pie!

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks, Captain. You have no idea how much that means to me.
You did your share of not-easying. But we worked through it.
Finally, Captain, you truly understand me!
This pie is delicious!
Oh, I can't put it down.
*ALARM*
Looks like you're going to have to, Henley. We've got one hell of a fight on our hands. Henley, it's been a pleasure. Now let's give this one everything we got!
@BATTLE
Watching those Morganas slink away to wherever the hell they came from is always my favorite part of this whole thing.
Even if I don't... there's no reason I can't make it better.
You won't do it alone.
Thanks... friend.
Any time.
Mine too. I wanted to thank you again, Captain... you really helped me put things in perspective.
Welcome to the present, Henley. I think you'll like it here.
